_meta.notes: Capitalization and running costs marked with isEstimate may be approximations from trade press

shows.title: All Out: Comedy About Ambition
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC filing (All In was $4.8M, All Out comparable)
shows.notes: Sequel to All In: Comedy About Love which recouped its $4.8M in just 10 weeks. Same format: rotating celebrity comedians with live band. Hit $2M+ weekly gross (record for a play). Very lean $200-300K weekly costs with 4-performer format. LIMITED RUN through March 8, 2026 - did NOT receive NY tax credit (missed application deadline by 2 months). Stars include Sarah Silverman, Ray Romano, Jason Mantzoukas.

shows.title: Art
shows.capitalizationSource: Broadway News confirmed $6.75M. SEC 'White Canvas Broadway LP' shows $6.9M max offering.
shows.notes: Bobby Cannavale, James Corden, Neil Patrick Harris revival. $6.75M cap (Broadway News confirmed, SEC 'White Canvas Broadway LP' $6.9M). Recouped week ending Dec 14, 2025 (~13 weeks into 16-week run). Weekly nut ~$725-750K — surprisingly high for 3-actor play due to star salaries (~$350K/week combined) and premium Broadway Journal ad spend. Averaged $1.2-1.8M gross at ~99% capacity. Matthew Warchus directed (also directed original 1996 production). Eligible for $3M NY tax credit.

shows.title: Bug
shows.notes: Broadway premiere at MTC's Samuel J. Friedman Theatre. Tracy Letts play directed by David Cromer. Transferred from Steppenwolf. Carrie Coon stars. Critics' Pick.

shows.title: CATS: The Jellicle Ball
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D filing (Jellicles Can Ltd Liability Co, CIK 0002098419, filed Dec 9, 2025). Range: $15M-$18M.
shows.notes: Reimagined immersive production of Cats. Opening April 7, 2026 at PAC NYC. Transferred from sold-out Perelman Performing Arts Center run. SEC filing under 'Jellicles Can Ltd Liability Co' shows $15M-$18M offering range (midpoint $16.5M used).

shows.title: Chess
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D/A filing (Chess Champion LLC, CIK 0002074648, amended Jan 5, 2026). Fully capitalized at $15M. Shubert Organization connection. c/o TT Partners.
shows.notes: Revival with Lea Michele and Aaron Tveit. Selling out regularly at ~$1.3-1.8M/week gross. Break-even ~$1.1M. Qualified for $3M NY theater tax credit (first preview Oct 15, 2025, just before Oct 20 deadline). At ~$500K weekly profit, could recoup by closing (June 14, 2026). Original 1988 production was $6M.

shows.title: Liberation
shows.notes: CORRECTION: Roundabout Theatre Company production at American Airlines Theatre, NOT commercial Daryl Roth production. Nonprofit model — no private investors, no recoupment concept. Bess Wohl world premiere. 6-person cast, single set. Weekly nut ~$350K. Roundabout received SVOG as institution but not specific to this show. Budget ~$3-5M funded through subscriber income, donations, and Roundabout's $47M annual budget.

shows.title: Mamma Mia!
shows.notes: 25th Anniversary Tour Broadway engagement (Aug 2025 - Feb 2026). See mamma-mia-2001 for original production.

shows.title: Marjorie Prime
shows.notes: Second Stage Theater production at Helen Hayes Theatre. Jordan Harrison play. Star cast: June Squibb, Cynthia Nixon, Danny Burstein. Critics' Pick.

shows.title: Oedipus
shows.notes: Mark Strong London transfer. $6.5M capitalization (SEC filings). Weekly cost ~$900K-1M. Grosses hovered near $937K/week, roughly breakeven. Limited run ended Feb 2026 without recouping. Investors likely lost capital.

shows.title: Proof
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D filing (Proof on Broadway Ltd Liability Co, CIK 0002098417, filed Dec 9, 2025). Range: $5M-$6.5M max.
shows.notes: Revival of David Auburn Pulitzer Prize-winning play. SEC Form D shows $5M min to $6.5M max capitalization (previously reported $9M from social media was incorrect). Limited 16-week run Apr-Jul 2026. Co-produced by Mike Bosner and Thomas Kail.

shows.title: Ragtime
shows.notes: Lincoln Center Theater revival. LCT operates on subscriber/nonprofit model - doesn't seek traditional recoupment. 32-member cast, 28-piece orchestra. Extended through June 2026. 100% capacity.

shows.title: The Queen of Versailles
shows.notes: Closed Dec 21, 2025 after weak ticket sales (moved up from Jan 4). $22.5M capitalization (NYT). Weekly nut ~$850K but grosses ~$700-800K at 75-81% capacity. Stephen Schwartz score. Kristin Chenoweth star vehicle couldn't save production. Deadline (Dec 9, 2025): 'among this season's largest investment losses.'

shows.title: Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York)
shows.notes: Forbes: 'most investor friendly new musical since the pandemic' - $8M cap with $480K weekly nut (two-hander with minimal production). Break-even ~$550K. Typical gross $0.65-0.75M at 80-95% capacity. MISSED NY tax credit deadline (first paid performance Nov 1, 2025 was after Oct 20 cutoff). Despite modest grosses, low overhead means it's hovering near break-even.

shows.title: Waiting for Godot
shows.notes: Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter revival. Opened Sep 2025, recouped $7.5M investment by week ending Nov 19, 2025 (~8 weeks). Jamie Lloyd directed.

shows.title: Boop! The Musical
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D/A filing (Broadwayboop LLC, CIK 0001968496, amended Jul 9, 2025). Max increased from $26M to $29M, fully capitalized.
shows.notes: Capitalized at $29M (SEC D/A, up from $26M). Closed July 13, 2025 after 112 performances. Weekly nut ~$750K but previews grossed only ~$530K (weekly loss ~$300K). Rarely grossed above $700K — consistently below breakeven. Investors lost ~80-100% of capital. David Foster composed. Jerry Mitchell directed/choreographed. William Haber / Ostar Enterprises. c/o Foresight Theatrical. Low ATP (~$70 previews) from heavy discounting for family audiences.

shows.title: Buena Vista Social Club
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D filing (Al Día News, Sept 2024)
shows.notes: Producer Orin Wolf noted it 'only cost $17 million' - modest for 2025 musical. Won 5 Tony Awards. Typical weekly gross $0.9-1.0M at 90-95% capacity. Break-even ~$0.85M. Broadway Journal: 'if they can weather the next year... may recoup in 12-18 months.' Eligible for $3M NY tax credit.

shows.title: Death Becomes Her
shows.notes: Most expensive show of 2024-2025 season. Grossed $63M+ in 46 weeks with $1.0-1.1M weekly costs. On track to recoup Spring 2026. Eligible for $3M NY tax credit (25% of costs up to $12M). Break-even ~$1.2M weekly.

shows.title: Glengarry Glen Ross
shows.notes: Kieran Culkin, Bob Odenkirk, Bill Burr revival (all Broadway debuts). $7.5M cap (SEC confirmed). Recouped in 9 weeks (May 12, 2025). Broke Palace Theatre box-office record ($2.4M gross). Weekly nut ~$925K — early weeks roughly broke even, then $1M+ weeks drove quick recoupment. Expected ~$1.9M NY state tax credit (25% of costs). Run extended twice. All-male cast throughout.

shows.title: Good Night, and Good Luck
shows.notes: George Clooney's Broadway debut. Adapted from his 2005 film with Grant Heslov. $9.5M capitalization recouped in just 7.5 weeks at the Winter Garden Theatre — one of the fastest recoupments of the season. David Cromer directed. Broke Winter Garden box office record with $4.3M weekly gross.

shows.title: Just in Time
shows.notes: Jonathan Groff star vehicle. Bobby Darin jukebox musical with $9.4M cap and $600K weekly costs. Averaging $1.2M+ weekly gross - recoupment imminent (likely Feb 2026). Strong reviews and Groff's star power driving consistent sales.

shows.title: Maybe Happy Ending
shows.notes: Critics' Pick. Darren Criss + Helen J Shen. Small cast reduces running costs. Struggled financially early but has been selling out consistently.

shows.title: Oh, Mary!
shows.notes: First show of 2024-2025 season to recoup. Transferred from sold-out Off-Broadway run. Weekly nut ~$300K (one of lowest on Broadway). Profit margin ~75%+ of gross. Broke Lyceum's 121-year box office record 9+ times, highest $1.354M/week. Total gross ~$91.8M on $4.525M investment. Cole Escola as writer/performer earned significant royalties + salary. U.S. tour planned 2026. Reddit: 'hard to see how it isn't one of the most profitable shows on Broadway post-pandemic.'

shows.title: Once Upon a Mattress
shows.notes: Sutton Foster-led Encores! transfer to Hudson Theatre. $8M capitalization (unconfirmed industry estimate). Reddit post-mortem: $650-$700K/week operating cost, $760K avg gross, 92% capacity, $110 ATP. Gross Less-Fees: $673K. 128 performances + 13 previews. Estimated operating loss $(1.0M)-$(285K). Did not come close to recouping. NYT Critics' Pick.

shows.title: Operation Mincemeat
shows.notes: West End hit transferred to Broadway. Weekly costs $500K vs London's £100K. Break-even ~$600K weekly but averaging $580K - running below break-even. Extended through Feb 2026 on strong word-of-mouth despite soft grosses.

shows.title: Othello
shows.recoupedSource: Variety / Playbill (May 1, 2025, announced alongside Tony nominations)
shows.notes: Denzel Washington & Jake Gyllenhaal. $9M cap. Recouped in 9 weeks (May 1, 2025). Shattered weekly Broadway play record with $2.82M gross (topping Harry Potter). Premium tickets reached $921. Highest-grossing play revival in world history. Expected ~$2M NY tax credit. 15-week limited run closed day of Tony Awards. Tony snub but producers announced recoupment as rejoinder. Washington likely had gross percentage deal.

shows.title: Our Town
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D/A filing (Grover's Corners Broadway LLC, CIK 0002020520, amended Jan 15, 2025). $5,976,500 capitalized. Range: $5M min, $6.5M max.
shows.notes: Jim Parsons-led revival at Barrymore Theatre. $5,976,500 capitalization (SEC Form D, 'Grover's Corners Broadway LLC'). Played to ~95% capacity, grossed $1.084M in final week. Recouped during limited run ending Jan 19, 2025. Previous $20M figure was likely a data error.

shows.title: Redwood
shows.notes: Idina Menzel star vehicle. $16M cap. Weekly nut ~$650K (Menzel's star salary was major expense). Grossed $800-900K at ~90% capacity in spring, yielding small weekly profits, but sales softened after Tony shutout. Closed May 18, 2025 after only 4 months. Menzel was only contracted through May — couldn't extend with replacement. Investors recovered estimated 20-30% of capital. Roundabout co-presented earlier Off-Broadway workshop.

shows.title: Romeo + Juliet
shows.notes: Kit Connor and Rachel Zegler in Sam Gold's immersive production at Circle in the Square (794 seats). $7M cap recouped during 20-week run — 'rare industry feat' for Shakespeare. Final week $1.48M. Highest-grossing limited engagement in CITS history. 14% of buyers age 18-24 (youngest Broadway audience demographics ever). Jack Antonoff provided music. Sonya Tayeh choreography. Run extended twice. ATP $150-180 via dynamic pricing. SRO tickets sold for additional revenue. Eligible for up to $1.75M tax credit.

shows.title: SMASH
shows.notes: Based on the NBC TV series. SEC Form D shows $23M offering with ~$20M raised. Weekly operating costs ~$800K (per Reddit grosses analysis). Closed June 22, 2025 after Tony shutout — ran 32 previews and 84 performances at the Imperial Theatre. One of three $20M+ musicals that flopped in 2024-2025 season (alongside Boop! and Tammy Faye).

shows.title: Stranger Things: The First Shadow
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D filing (Now A Warning LLC, CIK 0002040672, filed Oct 11, 2024). Range: $29M min, $31.5M max. c/o 321 Theatrical. Previous $20M estimate from Deep Research was too low.
shows.notes: Netflix/Sonia Friedman production. Won 4 Tony Awards 2025. SEC Form D shows $29M-$31.5M capitalization ('Now A Warning LLC' — largest Broadway capitalization found in EDGAR). Previous $20M estimate and Dec 2025 recoupment claim were based on incorrect cap figure. At $29M, show has likely NOT recouped (~$24M cumulative profit). Set Marquis Theatre record of $2.51M during Christmas week 2025. Season 5 finale boosted ticket sales significantly.

shows.title: Sunset Boulevard
shows.notes: Jamie Lloyd-directed revival starring Nicole Scherzinger. $15M capitalization. Weekly nut ~$950K. Won Tony for Best Actress (Scherzinger). Producer J.J. Powell confirmed $6M loss (~40% of cap) despite selling out and grossing $60M+ total. Jamie Lloyd invested $4M personally (~27% of cap) — unusual director-as-investor arrangement. Lloyd likely recouped his loss via director royalties (~1-2% of gross over 10 months). ALW's Really Useful Group took substantial composer/rights royalties. Scherzinger had high salary + possible gross percentage. Highest gross $2.5M in final week. Eligible for $3M tax credit (would reduce net loss to ~$3M).

shows.title: The Roommate
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC filing / industry sources (comparable to All In at $4.8M per SEC Form D)
shows.recoupedSource: Not recouped. No trade press confirmation (Deadline, Variety, Playbill, Broadway Journal all silent). Other 2024-25 plays that recouped (Oh, Mary!, Romeo + Juliet) were explicitly reported.
shows.notes: Star vehicle for Patti LuPone and Mia Farrow. Limited run closed as scheduled Dec 15, 2024 (previews from Aug 29). $4.8M cap, but weekly grosses (~$465K avg) barely covered estimated $400-500K weekly nut. Total all-time gross $6.97M over 113 performances. Operating profit was negligible (0-5% of cap). Eligible for NY State tax credit (up to $3M), which could push investor recovery to 60-70% — but payout is slow and not confirmed. No SVOG (post-pandemic). Producer: Chris Harper. Playwright royalties (Jen Silverman) carved out as operating expense.

shows.title: An Enemy of the People
shows.notes: Jeremy Strong and Michael Imperioli in Amy Herzog's Ibsen adaptation. $5.5M cap recouped during run at Circle in the Square (840 seats). Broke CITS weekly gross record 16 times during run. Final week record: $1,266,338 (prev record $917K by Hugh Jackman in The River). Joined Broadway's $1M Club for weekly grosses — almost unheard of for a non-musical. Strong won Tony for Best Actor. Digital lottery + cancellation line ensured 100%+ capacity some weeks. Eligible for ~$1.3M tax credit.

shows.title: Back to the Future: The Musical
shows.notes: Closed Jan 2025 without recouping despite $80M+ total ticket sales and 500+ performances. IMPORTANT DISTINCTION: Broadway Journal's $980K was the BREAKEVEN figure (operating cost + recoupment amortization of ~$155K/week over ~150 weeks). Pure operating nut was ~$825K. Even at $825K nut, show frequently grossed below breakeven — many weeks at $700-900K. West End production (opened 2021) more successful and still running. Received $3M NY state tax credit. NOT eligible for SVOG (was a London production during eligibility period). Robert Zemeckis and Bob Gale retained significant underlying rights royalties.

shows.title: Cabaret at the Kit Kat Club
shows.capitalizationSource: Broadway Journal ($24.25M actual raise from SEC filings)
shows.notes: Closed Oct 2025 without recouping. Actual capitalization $24.25M (not $26M). $7.5M of investor money used to convert Kit Kat Club venue owned by ATG (the lead producer's parent company). Active investor lawsuit alleging producers used investor funds to improve their own real estate. Weekly nut $1.5M proved unsustainable. Investors received 0% recovery.

shows.title: Hell's Kitchen
shows.notes: Closed Feb 22, 2026 without recouping. Returned ~60% of $22M to investors. Won 2 Tonys + Grammy. Alicia Keys had outsized insider profit participation: sole lead producer + underlying rights holder, earning 10% of net profits at recoupment (12.5% at 150%, 35% insider split at 200%). Similar structure to Harry Potter's Cursed Child. Had the show recouped, investors would have seen diluted returns. Weekly nut ~$750K. International productions planned may improve overall investor returns.

shows.title: Stereophonic
shows.notes: Record 13 Tony nominations for a play. $4.8M cap confirmed (SEC/NYT). Weekly nut ~$530K at Golden Theatre — Broadway Journal reported $541K gross was 'just above operating expenses.' OBC had unprecedented profit-sharing deal (tied to Tony wins) that slowed recoupment: cast earned bonuses per Tony, plus ongoing profit participation. Recouped Jan 8, 2025 during closing week. West End transfer + national tour announced. David Adjmi playwright retained significant creator royalties.

shows.title: Suffs
shows.capitalizationSource: SEC Form D/A filing (Young Are At the Gates LLC, CIK 0001953229, amended May 2024). $19M capitalized. Range: $17.5M min, $19.5M max.
shows.notes: Won Tony for Best Original Score but closed Jan 5, 2025 without recouping. Shaina Taub won two Tonys. Weekly nut ~$640K (breakeven ~$800K gross). Cast of 19. Often grossed only $500-700K in summer/fall (below nut), only hit capacity in final holiday weeks. Hillary Clinton and Malala Yousafzai co-producers. Frequently comped tickets to build word-of-mouth. SEC entities: 'Young Are At the Gates LLC' ($19M, main Broadway) + 'Wing Women On Broadway LLC' ($6.75M, development). Nearly total loss for investors (0-10% returned).

shows.title: The Great Gatsby
shows.capitalizationSource: Producer Chunsoo Shin (Gordon Cox / Korea Times)
shows.notes: First Broadway musical led by Korean producer (OD Company). BroadwayWorld: 'now appears unlikely' to recoup - grosses declined ~$250K/week in 2025 vs 2024. Break-even ~$1.0M but recent weeks at $0.9M (82% capacity). Eligible for $3M NY tax credit. Lavish Jazz Age production with 22-person cast, Tony-winning costumes.

shows.title: The Notebook
shows.notes: Nicholas Sparks musical adaptation. $15M capitalization (SEC/NYT, producer McCollum confirmed). Previous $22M figure was incorrect. Weekly nut ~$700K. Closed Dec 15, 2024 after ~300 performances without recouping. Estimated 60-80% of cap recovered. Final week grossed $1.0M ($225K profit). National tour planned for 2025. Underlying rights royalties (Sparks + Warner Bros) raised breakeven bar. Eligible for $3M NY state tax credit.

shows.title: The Outsiders
shows.notes: Won Best Musical Tony 2024. Recouped $22M investment week ending December 28, 2025 after 744 performances (89 weeks) and $121M+ total grosses. First new musical to recoup since Stranger Things (2022). Actors from developmental workshops entitled to profit-sharing per NYT.

shows.title: Water for Elephants
shows.notes: Closed Dec 8, 2024 without recouping despite 7 Tony nominations. $25M cap confirmed (NYT + SEC). Breakeven ~$960K gross/week but often fell short (e.g. 72% capacity, sub-$800K grosses early on). SEC: 'Benzini Bros LLC' ($8M) funded 2023 Atlanta tryout; additional LLCs raised remaining capital for Broadway. Peter Schneider / Big Red Barn Productions / Broadway Across America. Eligible for $3M NY state tax credit.

shows.title: & Juliet
shows.notes: Fourth new musical to recoup post-pandemic. Max Martin jukebox catalogue drives consistent grosses.

shows.title: Parade
shows.notes: Ben Platt-led revival of the 1998 Jason Robert Brown musical. $6.5M capitalization with $5.7M production costs. Weekly running cost ~$659K (Broadway Journal). Won Tony for Best Revival of a Musical 2023. Limited run March-August 2023 (~20 weeks). Received $3M NY state theater production tax credit, partially offsetting losses.

shows.title: MJ The Musical
shows.notes: Recouped in ~16 months. Received $10M SVOG grant. Has grossed over $200M. National tour also profitable. Note: Jackson Estate receives 100% of producer profit share — actual investor returns depend on estate's profit participation terms, which are not publicly disclosed. Weekly cost ~$1.3M. Recouped Nov 2023. $10M SVOG grant. Jackson Estate negotiated 100% of lead-producer profits + 13% off-the-top after recoup+10%.

shows.title: SIX
shows.recoupedSource: Playbill (Mar 23, 2023): 'As of December 2021, Broadway's SIX has recouped its investment.'
shows.notes: Low capitalization ($5-6.5M per SEC) + strong grosses = quick recoupment. Recouped by Dec 2021 (announced Mar 2023 retroactively). Received $10M SVOG grant (200% of $5M capitalization — largest SVOG-to-cap ratio among tracked shows). Was in previews when Broadway shut down Mar 2020. Reopened Oct 2021. Described as 'so cheap to run' on Reddit. Extended through Nov 2026. Multiple touring productions.

shows.title: Moulin Rouge! The Musical
shows.notes: Recouped ~3 years after opening (Nov 2022). Has grossed $194M+ on Broadway. Received $9.9M SVOG grant (via MRB Musical LLC) + $15M business interruption insurance settlement during COVID shutdown. Weekly operating nut ~$1.0-1.1M. $3M NY theater tax credit received (among first to qualify). Lavish production design at the Al Hirschfeld Theatre. Multiple international productions. Generating investor profits since Nov 2022 recoupment.

shows.title: Hadestown
shows.notes: First musical of 2018-2019 season to recoup. Won 8 Tony Awards including Best Musical. Recouped in ~30 weeks (6 months). Received $10M SVOG grant during COVID shutdown — one of at least 15 Broadway shows to receive the maximum grant. Grosses have softened recently but remains profitable. Received $10M federal SVOG grant during pandemic shutdown to support reopening.

shows.title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
shows.notes: Most expensive play ever to recoup, but investor returns are minimal. Per Broadway Journal (Boroff, Dec 2025), only $2.3M in profit distributions to investors (6% return over 7 years). High insider profit share (31% of net profits), $34M+ in theater rent to ATG, and $10M+ in producer royalties/fees absorbed most of the $456M gross. Posted $3.5M operating loss year ending Feb 2025.

shows.title: Hamilton
shows.notes: Recouped Broadway investment in ~10 weeks (often reported as '6 months' including Off-Broadway run at Public Theater). Currently grossing $600k+ weekly in profit. Multiple productions worldwide. Estimated total profit exceeds $1B.

shows.title: Aladdin
shows.capitalizationSource: Industry estimates ($15-17M range). Disney does not publicly disclose. LA Times reported $12M-$15M; some insiders estimated ~$20M. GPT DR Batch 3 consensus ~$15-17M.
shows.recoupedSource: Industry analysis (Broadway grosses vs. cumulative costs). Disney never formally announces recoupment.
shows.notes: Disney sole-funded production — no outside investors. Disney never announces recoupments: per insider, 'recoupment is not a concept that makes sense in the Disney model' since they handle many services in-house (marketing, ticketing, merchandise). $15-17M cap (Disney won't confirm). Recouped likely late 2014. Weekly nut ~$850K. Disney's unique New Amsterdam Theatre lease pays 2% of gross as rent (vs standard fixed rent of $50-100K/week), confirmed by GPT DR. Received $3M NY theater tax credit (2022-2023 fiscal year). By May 2023: $561M+ grossed, 3,100+ performances. NOT eligible for SVOG (Disney is a publicly traded company, per Variety Mar 2021). Multiple international productions. One of the most profitable Broadway shows of the 2010s.

shows.title: The Book of Mormon
shows.notes: Recouped in ~9 months. Multiple touring and international productions. Investors received multiple returns. Received $9.9M SVOG grant (per NY Business Journal Jul 2021).

shows.title: Wicked
shows.notes: Recouped in ~26 months (just over 2 years). Has grossed over $1.4B on Broadway alone. Film adaptation boosted 2024-2025 grosses significantly.

shows.title: The Lion King
shows.notes: Broadway's highest-grossing show of all time at $2B+. First show to hit $1B milestone (2013). Still running after 27+ years. NOT eligible for SVOG (Disney is a publicly traded company, per Variety Mar 2021).

shows.title: Chicago
shows.notes: Longest-running American musical in Broadway history. $700M+ Broadway gross. Low-cost concert staging was revolutionary. Weekly cost ~$250K. Recouped in 19 weeks (Mar 1997). $10M SVOG grant in 2021. Produced by Fran and Barry Weissler from Encores! concert.
